source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk1
evidence_span: A creep experiment on $2 3 \mathrm { - } \mathbf { m } \mathbf { m }$ diameter tubular specimens of Zircaloy-2 is described. The specimens are stressed biaxially at hoop stresses from 11 to $2 6 ~ \mathrm { k g f / m m ^ { 2 } }$ at $2 6 0 \mathrm { c }$ at three neutron flux conditions.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk1
evidence_span: fast neutrons increase creep rates at all the stresses tested, but thermal neutrons have no detectable effect

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk1
evidence_span: this is applied to cold-worked Zircaloy-2, cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated $2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ zirconium alloys

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk1

evidence_span: heat-treated $2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ zirconium alloys

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes in most of these reactors are subject to temperatures of 260 to $3 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$ , internal pressures of about $1 ~ \mathrm { k g f / n m ^ { 2 } }$ from the hot heavy-water fuel coolant, and fast-neutron fluxes of up to $3 ~ \times ~ 1 0 ^ { 1 3 }$ $\mathrm { n / c n ^ { 2 } s }$ $( > 1 \ \mathsf { M e V } )$

evidence_span: The tubing was manufactured in a similar manner to reactor pressure tubes, that is, extruded and cold-drawn 20 percent in one pass. It was then autoclaved at $4 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$ for $^ { 7 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$

evidence_span: The experiment operated for $8 9 1 0 \mathrm { h }$ at an average temperature of ${ 2 5 8 C }$ and an average pressure of $0 . 9 3 ~ \mathrm { k g / m m ^ { 2 } }$ .

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: The total fast-neutron flux $\displaystyle \{ > 1 \ \mathsf { M e V } \}$ received by the fast-flux specimens was $8 . 2 2 ~ \times ~ 1 0 ^ { 2 0 }$ nvt

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the average instantaneous flux being $2 . 5 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 3 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 } \mathrm { s }$

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: The thermal-flux specimens just above the reactor core were exposed to an average instantaneous thermal neutron flux of $1 . 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 4 } \mathrm { n / c m ^ { 2 } s }$

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: which diminished to $1 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 3 } \mathrm { n / c m ^ { 2 } s }$ for the specimens farthest from the reactor core

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: The creep rates and creep strains at $8 9 1 0 ~ \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ of the fast-flux specimens (Fig. 3) are 5 to 10 times greater than those of the thermalflux or out-of-fux specimens

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: Within the accuracy of measurement there was no detectable difference in creep of thermal-flux or out-of-flux specimens

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: The acceleration of creep rate due to a fast neutron flux of $2 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 3 } ~ \mathrm { { \textmu } / c m ^ { 2 } s }$ and $2 6 0 \mathrm { C }$ at $9 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ is a factor of about l0

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the acceleration being greater at the lower stresses than at the higher stresses

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the uniaxial test temperatures are $3 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the tubes receive about four times nore fast-neutron flux than the uniaxial tests

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the creep rate is directly proportional to (T-160) C between 250 and $3 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk2
evidence_span: the creep rate is directly proportional to the fastneutron flux

evidence_span: the rates for the uniaxial tests are three to four times higher at similar stresses

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: texture coefficients for all the alloys together with the resolved fraction of slip planes in the hoop (transverse) and longitudinal directions

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: all the slip planes for diametral creep in both coldworked alloys are due to (C+CB) texture, the-hoop stress should be adjusted by a factor of 0.5

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: out-of-pile creep tests on all three materials [8-10] showed similar creep rates for transverse and longitudinal specimens

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium has slip planes for diametral creep due to both CB and D texture

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: no adjustment should be necessary to compare biaxial tube creep rates with uniaxial rates for heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium
